title: The Rugby World Cup’s Must-Have Accessory: a Kiwi Coach
text:
If the past two decades of rugby have taught us anything, it’s that the World Cup is essentially a six-week exercise in figuring out whether anyone can knock off New Zealand. The answer is usually no.

The All Blacks are the most powerful national side the sport has ever seen. They have won the World Cup three times and are heavy favorites to make it four. The last time New Zealand lost a match at this tournament, most of the current team was in middle school.

So in order to close the gap on the Kiwis, national teams around the world turn to the most Kiwi thing they can think of: they hire Kiwi coaches. When the World Cup kicks off on Friday, seven of the 20 national team coaches will be from New Zealand, along with at least a dozen assistants.

For a country at the end of the world that occasionally gets left off maps, this is better than usual representation. With a population of 4.8 million people, that means roughly 1 in every 700,000 New Zealanders is leading a team at this Rugby World Cup. And most of them are facing impossible odds. The non-New Zealand teams in the hands of New Zealanders include Fiji, Georgia, Ireland, Samoa, Wales and the host nation Japan.

“Trying to do things that no one else has ever done before is a hallmark of what New Zealand people are about,” All Blacks coach Steven Hansen said. “We came away from the home shores and settled in a country at the bottom of the earth.”

New Zealand All Blacks coach Steve Hansen, center, watches his players during a training session at Kashiwanoha Park Stadium. Photo: behrouz mehri/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images

On the most basic level, teams looking to improve by hiring New Zealanders makes perfect sense. If you were competing at the World Cup of croissants, you would probably want a French coach. And if you’re a nation competing at the World Cup of rugby—and you don’t have historical beef with New Zealand—then the logic is the same: You want a New Zealander.

The sport may have been invented on the playing fields of England, but no one has perfected the game like the All Blacks. Their all-time win rate is 77%. The team combines style, athleticism, and attacking creativity in a way that makes them electric to watch and automatic favorites no matter who they’re playing.

Yet few other sports have seen the same kind of coaching diaspora. Even last year’s World Baseball Classic—perhaps the most American tournament in international sports—featured a lower percentage of U.S.-born managers than the Rugby World Cup’s 35% of Kiwi coaches.

This stampede across international rugby isn’t happening in a vacuum. It’s a consequence of the already Kiwi-packed club game, where New Zealand-born coaches are as popular as post-match beers. In the past season of Super Rugby, the league that brings together the top teams in the Southern Hemisphere, eight of the 15 coaches were Kiwis. Even its Northern Hemisphere equivalent, the European Rugby Champions Cup, saw a quarter of the teams led by New Zealanders.

But on the international stage, Kiwi coaching can take you only so far if you don’t have Kiwi players. Tonga, for instance, which has former All Black Dan Cron for an assistant coach, received a violent reminder of that against New Zealand earlier this month.

“It’s a big motivating factor when you lose 92-7,” said Cron, whose father is the All Blacks’ forwards coach. “Players don’t like losing by that much, especially when it’s on national television.”

Wales coach Warren Gatland looks on as players warm up before a match. Photo: rebecca naden/Reuters

So for most New Zealanders venturing far from home, the mission is really about bringing a sprinkling of New Zealand’s rugby know-how to countries with less developed programs. Joe Schmidt and Warren Gatland, in charge of Ireland and Wales, respectively, are exceptions rather than the rule. More typical is World Cup host Japan. The tournament hosts hired former All Black Jamie Joseph in 2016 in the hopes of advancing from the World Cup group stage for the first time in its history.

“Our game is based around speed, skill and structure,” said Joseph. “But the key difference this year is we are fit enough now to play that game. We’re training at a level of intensity that’s 25% higher than our matches. I think that’s our key weapon.”

Where many countries may never catch the All Blacks is on the talent production front. New Zealand’s pipeline never seems to run dry. By the time they pull on the hallowed black jersey, young players are already versed in the All Blacks’ style at the All Blacks’ level of excellence. In a place with barely the population of Alabama, the coaching at all levels has plenty to do with it.

Joe Schmidt, right, leads Ireland’s squad. Photo: Matteo Ciambelli/NurPhoto/Zuma Press

The other aspect is Kiwi culture. Even though rugby participation has fallen behind soccer, according to a study by Sport New Zealand, it still attracts the cream of all youth athletes. Few things mean more in New Zealand than receiving a call-up to the All Blacks, where every player ever to represent the team has a unique number stitched into his jersey. This is an outfit for whom every defeat is catastrophic. For all of its exported rugby knowledge, New Zealand knows that no one can match the demands it places on its own national team.

“The World Cup is the biggest stage for rugby but I know definitely for me, there’s always pressure on a black jersey,” All Blacks center Anton Lienert-Brown said. “We’re always expected not just to win, but to win well.”

The irony is in how many of the people plotting to stop them happen to hold the same passport.

Write to Joshua Robinson at joshua.robinson@wsj.com
description: New Zealanders, preaching the world’s most successful rugby gospel, are in charge of seven of the tournament’s 20 teams.
